items.title: NASA delays Artemis II moon launch
items.summary_auto: NASA is delaying its upcoming Orion spacecraft launch at least until March, after engineers experienced 'several challenges' during a wet dress rehearsal for the Artemis II moon mission.

items.title: BMO fined $4M by consumer watchdog for overcharging customers on discounted plans
items.summary_auto: The Financial Consumer Agency of Canada says it has applied a $4 million penalty on Bank of Montreal for overcharging customers after it failed to properly disclose fee details.

items.title: Iran's president seeks 'fair and equitable negotiations' with the U.S.
items.summary_auto: Iran's president said Tuesday he instructed the country's foreign minister to "pursue fair and equitable negotiations" with the United States, the first clear sign from Tehran it wants to try to negotiate as tensions remain high with Washington after the Mideast country's bloody crackdown on nationwide protests last month.

items.title: Clintons appear ready to testify in Congress about Jeffrey Epstein after contempt threat
items.summary_auto: Former U.S. president Bill Clinton and Hillary Clinton, the 2016 Democratic presidential nominee, will testify in a congressional investigation into the late sex offender Jeffrey Epstein, a staffer said on Monday.

items.title: Stream of sports betting ads from outside Manitoba trigger former gambling addict, he says
items.summary_auto: Teddy Wojtowicz says he feels triggered by the abundance of betting ads he sees while watching sports on TV.

items.title: Schools delayed opening as parts of Newfoundland dig out from storm
items.summary_auto: More than 40 cm of snow fell on the capital city, resulting in a mess that's causing delayed openings for schools, businesses and government services.

items.title: Rape trial begins in Oslo for son of Norway's crown princess
items.summary_auto: The trial of the son of Norway's crown princess, on charges that include rape, started on Tuesday, opening weeks of proceedings in a case that has cast a shadow on the royal family's image.

items.title: Partner of N.L. man who died waiting in hospital ER calling for inquiry
items.summary_auto: Robert Power, 69, died after a long wait for emergency care at the Carbonear General Hospital. His wife is calling for an inquiry into his death.

items.title: What we know (so far) about the people accused in London, Ont., bomb-making scheme
items.summary_auto: Three men and one woman who are currently attending, or are alumni of, Western University face a slew of charges alleging — among other things — that they were storing chemicals that could be made into explosives at a house just west of campus in London, Ont. Here's what we know about them.

items.title: How a new, more sustainable lithium mining process could kick off the industry in Western Canada
items.summary_auto: As demand — and competition — for critical minerals used in clean technologies heats up around the world, mining startups are flocking to the heart of Canada’s oil and gas industry to tap into a key battery metal: lithium.

items.title: Gaps in menopause care push some Canadians to pay out of pocket
items.summary_auto: Some Canadians are paying for menopause care from a host of private practitioners opening clinics outside the public health-care system.

items.title: Costco's beloved rotisserie chicken gets roasted in lawsuit over preservatives
items.summary_auto: In a time of skyrocketing food prices and turbulent economic times, Costco's rotisserie chickens are, for many, a reliable meal mainstay. But a new lawsuit filed in a California court has a bone to pick with how the retailer advertises its beloved cooked birds.

items.title: Ontario's 'troubling' surge in unclaimed bodies is not letting up
items.summary_auto: The number of bodies that go unclaimed every year in Ontario continues to reach new record levels, according to the latest figures from the Office of the Chief Coroner.

items.title: What happens in ICE detention?
items.summary_auto: “Cruel and inhuman”: The disturbing details of what it’s like behind bars inside Trump’s ever-expanding ICE detention system.

items.title: Toronto's transit map got its biggest upgrade in decades. Here's the cartographer behind it
items.summary_auto: You've probably noticed the Eglinton Crosstown LRT already showing up on transit maps, even though it's not open. That's the work of the TTC's cartographer, tasked with the map's biggest upgrade in decades.

items.title: Why was Jeffrey Epstein allowed into Canada in 2014?
items.summary_auto: Nearly six years after pleading guilty to a crime that should have made him inadmissible, Jeffrey Epstein visited Canada, and federal government officials are providing no answers about why he was allowed into the country.

items.title: BetMGM moves to explicitly prohibit customers from harassing athletes
items.summary_auto: BetMGM said on Monday it is updating its terms of service to explicitly prohibit customers from harassing athletes, a move the U.S. sports-betting operator ​framed as part of a broader push on sports integrity and player safety.

items.title: Estée Lauder pleads guilty, pays $750K fine for using undeclared 'forever chemicals' in some eyeliners
items.summary_auto: Cosmetics company Estée Lauder has been fined $750,000 after federal agents found it was using "forever chemicals" in some of its eyeliner products.

items.title: 3 junior hockey players killed in Alberta crash. Here is what we know about the collision and players
'Heartbreaking day' for hockey community after 3 junior players killed in Alberta crash
Calgary man found guilty of tunnelling into upstairs neighbour's apartment
items.summary_auto: A Calgary man who tunnelled from his apartment to that of his upstairs neighbour last summer has been found guilty of break and enter.

items.title: Alberta UCP caucus has 'no business' signing separation vote petition: former premier
items.summary_auto: Former Alberta premier Jason Kenney says the governing United Conservative Party caucus has "no business" signing a petition to force a vote on the province quitting Canada.

items.title: What we still don't know about the Michael Jackson biopic after that trailer
items.summary_auto: Lionsgate released the trailer to Michael, its Michael Jackson biopic on Monday. The trailer answers a few questions about one of the most anticipated films of 2026 — while leaving a host of others up in the air.

items.title: Auto production by Detroit Three declines in Canada as Japanese automakers lead the way, report says
items.summary_auto: While Canadian production and jobs with Ford, Stellantis and General Motors have declined over the past decade, they have stayed consistent among Japanese carmakers, according to a new report by the Trillium Network for Advanced Manufacturing, an Ontario-based think-tank.

items.title: Melania documentary: Bold or just bad?
items.summary_auto: Andrew Chang explains the critical and box office response to the documentary film of the United States First Lady Melania Trump. Images provided by The Canadian Press, Reuters and Getty Images

items.title: Body cameras being immediately issued to ICE agents in Minneapolis
items.summary_auto: Every U.S. Homeland Security officer on the ground in Minneapolis, including Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE) officers, will be immediately issued body-worn cameras, Secretary Kristi Noem said Monday.

items.title: U.S. judge grants asylum to Chinese whistleblower who got scooped up in ICE raid
items.summary_auto: A Chinese whistleblower fled to the U.S. with footage of detention camps and requested asylum, only to be arrested by ICE agents and face deportation to Uganda. Now, five years after his saga began, his asylum claim has been granted.

items.title: Arizona police suspect Today show host's mother taken from home against her will
items.summary_auto: Authorities believe the 84-year-old mother of NBC's Today show host Savannah Guthrie was kidnapped, abducted or otherwise taken against her will, and the sheriff said Monday it's imperative she's found soon because she could die without her medication.

items.title: Fact check: Fake Grammys photo of Justin Trudeau and Katy Perry
items.summary_auto: No, Justin Trudeau and Katy Perry were not photographed at the Grammys on Sunday. But these fake photos were shared widely online.

items.title: NASA's moon rocket experiences fuel leak during critical test ahead of launch
items.summary_auto: NASA ran into a leak while fuelling its new moon rocket Monday in one final make-or-break test that will determine when astronauts can launch on a lunar fly-around.

items.title: Hamilton soldier who died in Latvia to be honoured at repatriation ceremony
items.summary_auto: A Hamilton soldier who died in Latvia last week will be honoured at a repatriation ceremony on Tuesday in Quinte West in southern Ontario.

items.title: B.C. premier doubles down on calling Alberta separatist movement seeking U.S. support 'treason'
items.summary_auto: Calgary-based data analyst John Santos warns that that kind of language could push people toward separatism.

items.title: Olympic appeal for U.S. skeleton racer who accused Canada of sabotage is outside jurisdiction: sports court
items.summary_auto: U.S. skeleton racer Katie Uhlaender's last chance to make the Olympic field may have been lost Monday, with the Court of Arbitration for Sport saying it lacks the jurisdiction to change the result of a race that could have earned her a berth in the Milan-Cortina Winter Games.

items.title: Financiers who defrauded investors in Man. and Ont. projects each sentenced to 5 years in jail, $12 million
items.summary_auto: Jawad Rathore, 49, and 50-year-old Vince Petrozza were executives for Fortress Real Developments Inc., a defunct Toronto-area syndicated mortgage company that raised funds for a failed 45-storey tower in downtown Winnipeg called SkyCity and a Barrie mixed-use development called the Collier Centre.

items.title: ‘Gifted’ dogs can learn new words just by eavesdropping
items.summary_auto: Researchers have identified that some dogs are "gifted word learners” — pups who know the names of more than 100 toys. In fact, these dogs can learn new words just by eavesdropping. And even if your dog isn’t in this "gifted" group, there are many ways to help them improve how they learn.

items.title: Former minister Bill Blair appointed to diplomatic post, resigns as MP
items.summary_auto: Former Liberal cabinet minister Bill Blair resigned as an MP on Monday after the Prime Minister's Office announced that he will be Canada's next high commissioner to the U.K.

items.title: IN PHOTOS | Best of Westminster Kennel Club dog show
items.summary_auto: The annual Westminster Kennel Club Dog Show is underway, and over 3,000 dogs from around the world have gathered in New York City to participate in various competitions.

items.title: Water levels in Badger, Nfld., lowering, but evacuation order remains in place
items.summary_auto: The mayor of Badger says water levels are falling as the town faces a risk of major flooding, but it's still too early to know when evacuated residents can return to their homes.
